The following test case has no assertions...

public void testIllegalArgumentException() {
try {
MyClass myClass = new MyClass(null);
fail("Created myClass with null argument.");
}
catch (IllegalArgumentException success) {
}
}

...should I be worried that this test isn't good enough?

Subject: [junit] RE: Why doesn't JUnit count asserts?





>As an aside, we count asserts instead of tests because it's a finer
grained
>metric.  Right now we only have 8 functional test methods, but 170
>assertions.  When we add to a functional test we don't create a new test
>method, we add some more assertions to an already existing test.  It would
>be harder to see progress if we tracked test cases.

My version of JUnit doesn't count asserts, but it probably should, so it
would provide a warning if a testcase has no assertions in it.
